user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_set_thread_name_:
```c
static int
MHD_set_thread_name_ (const MHD_thread_ID_native_ thread_id,
                      const char *thread_name)
{
  if (NULL == thread_name)
    return 0;

#if defined(HAVE_PTHREAD_SETNAME_NP_GNU)
  return ! pthread_setname_np (thread_id, thread_name);
#elif defined(HAVE_PTHREAD_SET_NAME_NP_FREEBSD)
  /* FreeBSD and OpenBSD use different function name and void return type */
  pthread_set_name_np (thread_id, thread_name);
  return ! 0;
#elif defined(HAVE_PTHREAD_SETNAME_NP_NETBSD)
  /* NetBSD use 3 arguments: second argument is string in printf-like format,
   *                         third argument is a single argument for printf();
   * OSF1 use 3 arguments too, but last one always must be zero (NULL).
   * MHD doesn't use '%' in thread names, so both form are used in same way.
   */
  return ! pthread_setname_np (thread_id, thread_name, 0);
#endif /* HAVE_PTHREAD_SETNAME_NP_NETBSD */
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_set_thread_name_:
#define HAVE_PTHREAD_SETNAME_NP_GNU 1
...
typedef pthread_t MHD_thread_ID_native_
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No calls to any of the <string.h> functions listed in MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (e.g., memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn) are present in the provided code. The function only performs a NULL check on thread_name and then calls platform-specific pthread_setname_np variants; these are not functions from <string.h> and any internal implementation they may have is outside the scope of this source-level check. There are no explicit buffer copies, length computations, or uses of pointer arithmetic on character buffers in the shown code or in the provided related definitions, so no fragments need further investigation for Rule 21.17.
